ground_truth: Michal carries a bag of provisions and puts them on a table while Szpilman goes immediately to the window and looks out. There are views of the city, but in the street below, opposite, is a hospital and, on the corner, a building flying a Nazi flag and guarded by a sentry, standing at his sentry-box. Michal comes up behind Szpilman, makes for the door, nods, and goes. The sound of the padlock closing. Szpilman takes in the room, sees the piano, is still for a moment, then goes to it. He sits on the piano stool, adjusts its height, opens the lid, removes a cloth covering the keys, gazes lovingly at the keyboard, and flexes his fingers. Then, without touching the keys, his fingers floating just above them, he plays passionately. Snow falling. Szpilman alert, hearing the padlock being unlocked and then opened. The door opens and Michal enters, accompanied by a man, aged about thirty, Szalas, confident, a little brash. In whispers, Szalas and Szpilman shake hands. Szalas produces a quarter bottle of vodka, thumps the back of the bottle so that the cork flies out. He finds glasses and pours, gives the others their vodka. Szalas shrugs, finds the vodka, pours two glasses, unwraps the package to reveal sausage and bread, takes a bite of sausage, chewing deliberately, slowly. Szalas goes to the window, looks out. Szpilman thinks for a moment, then takes off his wristwatch, hands it to Szalas. Szalas pockets the watch, makes for the door, stops, grins, downs Szpilman's vodka, gives a mock salute and goes. The padlock is locked on the other side. Sunshine floods in through the windows. Szpilman lies inert on the bed, weak, starving, ill. The sound of the padlock. Dorota, no longer pregnant, and Michal enter, come to the bed. In whispers, Szpilman barely has strength to open his eyes and focus on them. He mutters incoherently. She starts for the door, and he leaves. The padlock sound. Dorota goes to the kitchen, wets a towel, comes back to the bed, kneels it, places the towel on Szpilman's brow. He focuses on her, smiles, then suddenly winces with pain. She looks at him, barely audible. The Doctor and Michal leave his line of vision. Szpilman looking down from the fourth-floor window. Peaceful. A few pedestrians. An everyday atmosphere. At the far end, at the T-junction with a main road, a tram rumbles down the street and comes to a halt, disgorging passengers on the far side and so out of sight. The tram continues on its way, now revealing the few passengers who alighted—women, an old man with a stick.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Michal transports a sack of supplies and places them on a table while Szpilman proceeds instantly to the window and peers out. There are vistas of the metropolis, but in the avenue beneath, opposite, is a clinic and, on the corner, an edifice displaying a Nazi banner and overseen by a guard, positioned at his sentry-box. Michal approaches behind Szpilman, heads for the door, nods, and departs. The noise of the padlock fastening. Szpilman surveys the chamber, observes the piano, remains motionless for a moment, then advances to it. He perches on the piano stool, modifies its height, lifts the lid, takes off a fabric concealing the keys, stares fondly at the keyboard, and stretches his fingers. Then, without contacting the keys, his fingers hovering just above them, he plays fervently. Snow descending. Szpilman attentive, hearing the padlock being unfastened and then opened. The door opens and Michal enters, accompanied by a gentleman, aged about thirty, Szalas, self-assured, somewhat bold. In murmurs, Szalas and Szpilman clasp hands. Szalas reveals a quarter bottle of vodka, knocks the back of the bottle so that the cork ejects. He locates glasses and pours, hands the others their vodka. Szalas shrugs, locates the vodka, pours two glasses, unwraps the parcel to disclose sausage and bread, takes a nibble of sausage, chewing intently, slowly. Szalas proceeds to the window, peers out. Szpilman contemplates for a moment, then removes his wristwatch, hands it to Szalas. Szalas pockets the watch, heads for the door, halts, grins, consumes Szpilman's vodka, gives a mock salute and departs. The padlock is secured on the other side. Sunshine inundates through the windows. Szpilman lies motionless on the bed, feeble, famished, ill. The sound of the padlock. Dorota, no longer expecting, and Michal come in, approach the bed. In murmurs, Szpilman scarcely has power to open his eyes and concentrate on them. He mutters incoherently. She moves for the door, and he departs. The padlock noise. Dorota goes to the kitchen, moistens a towel, returns to the bed, kneels it, places the towel on Szpilman's forehead. He concentrates on her, smiles, then abruptly grimaces with agony. She gazes at him, barely audible. The Doctor and Michal exit his line of sight. Szpilman gazing down from the fourth-floor window. Serene. A few walkers. An ordinary ambiance. At the distant extremity, at the T-intersection with a main road, a tram clatters down the avenue and comes to a stop, discharging commuters on the distant side and so out of view. The tram continues on its route, now unveiling the few commuters who descended—women, an elderly man with a cane.

test_cases.description: A bag of provisions is carried by Michal and placed on a table by him while the window is immediately approached by Szpilman, and he looks out. Views of the city are present, but a hospital is in the street below, opposite, and a building flying a Nazi flag is on the corner, guarded by a sentry who stands at his sentry-box. Szpilman is approached from behind by Michal, who then makes for the door, nods, and leaves. The padlock is heard being closed. The room is taken in by Szpilman, the piano is seen by him, and he is still for a moment, then it is approached by him. He sits on the piano stool, its height is adjusted by him, the lid is opened, a cloth covering the keys is removed, and the keyboard is gazed at lovingly by him as he flexes his fingers. Then, his fingers floating just above them, the keys are touched by him passionately, though not physically played. Snow is falling. The padlock being unlocked and opened is heard by Szpilman, who is alert. The door opens and Michal enters, bringing with him a man, aged about thirty, Szalas, confident, a little brash. In whispers, hands are shaken by Szalas and Szpilman. A quarter bottle of vodka is produced by Szalas, the back of the bottle is thumped by him, causing the cork to fly out. Glasses are found, and vodka is poured by him, given to the others. The vodka is found by Szalas, two glasses are poured by him, a package is unwrapped to reveal sausage and bread, a bite of sausage is taken by him, and it is chewed deliberately, slowly. The window is approached by Szalas, and he looks out. After thinking for a moment, Szpilman takes off his wristwatch and hands it to Szalas. The watch is pocketed by Szalas, who makes for the door, stops, grins, consumes Szpilman's vodka, gives a mock salute, and leaves. The padlock is locked from the other side. Sunshine floods in through the windows. The bed is laid upon, inert, by Szpilman, who is weak, starving, and ill. The padlock is heard. Dorota, no longer pregnant, and Michal enter, approach the bed. In whispers, Szpilman barely musters the strength to open his eyes and focus on them. Incoherent mutters are made by him. The door is started for by her, and he leaves. The sound of the padlock. The kitchen is approached by Dorota, who wets a towel, then returns to the bed, kneels on it, and places the towel on Szpilman's brow. Her focus is on him, and he smiles, then suddenly winces with pain. She looks at him, her voice barely audible. The Doctor and Michal leave his line of vision. The fourth-floor window is looked down from by Szpilman. Peaceful. A few pedestrians. An everyday atmosphere. At the far end, at the T-junction with a main road, a tram rumbles down the street and halts, disgorging passengers on the far side and then out of sight. The tram moves on, now revealing the few passengers who alighted—women, an old man with a stick.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Michal places a bag of supplies on a table while Szpilman immediately looks out the window. He sees the city and a hospital below, with a building flying a Nazi flag, guarded by a sentry. Michal nods and leaves, the padlock clicking shut. Szpilman surveys the room, notices the piano, sits, adjusts the stool, opens the lid, uncovers the keys, and lovingly gazes at them before playing passionately without touching them. Snow falls. Alert, Szpilman hears the padlock unlock. Michal enters with Szalas, who is confident and a bit brash. Szalas produces vodka, pops the cork, finds glasses, and serves it. He unwraps sausage and bread, eating slowly. At the window, Szalas looks out. Szpilman thinks, removes his wristwatch, and gives it to Szalas, who pockets it, grins, downs Szpilman's vodka, and leaves with a mock salute. The padlock is secured outside. Sunlight floods in. Szpilman lies weak and ill on the bed. The padlock sounds again. Dorota and Michal enter quietly. Szpilman, weak, barely opens his eyes and mutters. Dorota goes to the kitchen, wets a towel, and places it on Szpilman's brow as he smiles and winces. She speaks softly. The Doctor and Michal leave his sight. Szpilman looks down from the fourth-floor window. It is peaceful, with a few pedestrians and an everyday feel. At the T-junction, a tram halts, unloading passengers, then continues, revealing women and an old man with a stick.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Michal places provisions on a table as Szpilman looks out the window, noting city views, a hospital, and a Nazi-guarded building. Michal nods and leaves, locking the door. Szpilman observes the room, then sits at the piano, adjusts the stool, opens the lid, uncovers the keys, and lovingly prepares to play without touching them. Snow falls as Michal and Szalas, a confident man, enter. Szpilman and Szalas shake hands. Szalas produces vodka, pours it, reveals sausage and bread, and eats. Szpilman gives Szalas his watch, who pockets it, drinks Szpilman's vodka, salutes, and leaves as the padlock clicks. Sunlight floods in, revealing a weak Szpilman on the bed. Dorota, no longer pregnant, and Michal enter quietly. Szpilman barely opens his eyes, muttering. She leaves, and Michal exits with the padlock sound. Dorota dampens a towel, places it on Szpilman's brow, and he smiles before wincing in pain. He sees pedestrians and a tram halt, then move, revealing women and an old man with a stick on the street.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Carrying a sturdy bag filled with provisions, Michal enters the room and places these essential supplies carefully onto a nearby table. Without wasting a moment, Szpilman makes his way directly to the window, peering out with a sense of urgency. The window offers expansive views of the city, but in the street below, immediately opposite the building, stands a hospital. Nearby, on the street corner, a building is noticeable for its prominently displayed Nazi flag, guarded vigilantly by a sentry, who stands at attention next to his designated sentry-box.

Michal approaches Szpilman from behind, quietly signaling his intention to leave as he makes his way towards the door. He gives a nod of acknowledgment, then exits. The distinct sound of a padlock being closed fills the room. Szpilman takes a moment to absorb his surroundings within the room, his eyes catching sight of the piano. He pauses momentarily, contemplative, before approaching the instrument. Settling onto the piano stool, he adjusts its height to his liking, opens the lid with care, and removes the protective cloth that covers the keys. His gaze lingers lovingly on the keyboard as he flexes his fingers in preparation. Then, with his fingers hovering just above the keys, he begins to play passionately, though without producing any sound.

Meanwhile, snow gently falls outside. Szpilman becomes alert at the familiar sound of the padlock being unlocked and opened. The door swings open, and Michal re-enters, now accompanied by Szalas, a man of about thirty, who exudes confidence and carries himself with a slightly brash demeanor. In whispered tones, Szalas and Szpilman exchange greetings with a handshake. Szalas produces a quarter bottle of vodka, skillfully thumping the back of the bottle until the cork pops out energetically. He finds glasses, pours the vodka generously, and offers it to the others. With a casual shrug, Szalas uncovers more provisions, pouring two glasses of vodka, unwrapping a package to reveal sausage and bread. He takes a deliberate bite of the sausage, chewing in a slow, thoughtful manner. Szalas then moves towards the window and glances out thoughtfully. Szpilman, after a brief moment of contemplation, removes his wristwatch and hands it over to Szalas. Szalas pockets the watch, heads towards the door but pauses, grins mischievously, downs Szpilman's vodka in one go, gives a mock salute, and departs. Once again, the sound of the padlock being secured resonates from the other side.

As sunshine floods through the windows, illuminating the room, Szpilman lies motionless on the bed, weakened by hunger and illness. The familiar sound of the padlock is heard once again, followed by the entrance of Dorota—no longer expecting—and Michal, who approach the bed with concern. In hushed whispers, Szpilman struggles to muster the strength to open his eyes and focus on them, muttering incoherently. Dorota makes her way towards the door, and Michal leaves. The closure of the padlock is heard again. Dorota moves to the kitchen, wets a towel, and returns to the bedside. Kneeling beside Szpilman, she tenderly places the cool, damp towel on his fevered brow. He manages to focus on her and offers a weary smile but suddenly winces in pain. She gazes at him with concern, her words barely audible. The Doctor and Michal quietly leave his line of sight.

From a window on the fourth floor, Szpilman gazes downwards, observing a landscape of peace. A few pedestrians meander below, contributing to an everyday atmosphere. In the distance, at the T-junction with a main road, a tram makes its way down the street, eventually coming to a halt as it disgorges passengers on the far side, momentarily out of sight. The tram then resumes its journey, now revealing the few passengers who had alighted—women and an elderly man leaning on a stick.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Carrying a sturdy bag filled with various essential provisions, Michal steps into the room with a deliberate, measured gait, carefully placing these vital supplies onto a nearby table with an air of attentiveness. Without hesitating for a second, Szpilman makes his way directly to the window, driven by a palpable sense of urgency. This particular window offers expansive, panoramic views of the cityscape, but in the street below, directly across from the building, stands a hospital. Nearby, at the street corner, a building is notably marked by a prominently displayed Nazi flag, which is being guarded vigilantly by a sentry who stands attentively at his designated post beside the sentry-box.

Michal approaches Szpilman from behind in a quiet manner, signaling his intention to leave as he moves purposefully towards the door. He gives a nod of acknowledgment, then takes his leave. The room fills with the distinct sound of a padlock being securely closed. Szpilman takes a moment to absorb his surroundings within the confines of the room, his eyes eventually catching sight of the piano. He pauses momentarily, lost in contemplation, before moving towards the instrument. Settling onto the piano stool, he carefully adjusts its height to suit his preference, opens the lid with care, and gently removes the protective cloth that covers the keys. His gaze lingers lovingly on the keyboard as he flexes his fingers in anticipation of what is to come. Then, with his fingers hovering above the keys, he begins to play passionately, feeling the music internally, though it remains silent to the ear.

Meanwhile, outside, snow falls gently, creating a serene atmosphere. Szpilman becomes alert at the familiar, distinct sound of the padlock being unlocked and opened. The door swings open, and Michal re-enters, now accompanied by Szalas, a man in his thirties who exudes a confident aura and carries himself with a slightly brash demeanor. In whispered tones, Szalas and Szpilman exchange greetings, sealing the exchange with a handshake. Szalas skillfully produces a quarter bottle of vodka, thumping the back of the bottle energetically until the cork pops out. He finds some glasses, pours the vodka generously, and offers it to the others. With a casual shrug, Szalas uncovers more provisions, pouring two glasses of vodka and unwrapping a package to reveal sausage and bread. He takes a deliberate bite of the sausage, chewing in a slow, thoughtful manner. Szalas then moves towards the window, glancing out thoughtfully for a moment. Szpilman, after a brief period of contemplation, removes his wristwatch and hands it over to Szalas. Szalas pockets the watch, heads towards the door but pauses, grins mischievously, downs Szpilman's vodka in one swift motion, gives a mock salute, and departs. Once again, the sound of the padlock being secured resonates from the other side.

As beams of sunshine flood through the windows, illuminating the room with a warm glow, Szpilman lies motionless on the bed, weakened significantly by hunger and illness. The familiar sound of the padlock is heard once again, followed by the entrance of Dorota—no longer expecting—and Michal, who both approach the bed with visible concern etched on their faces. In hushed whispers, Szpilman struggles to muster the strength to open his eyes and focus on them, muttering incoherently. Dorota makes her way towards the door, and Michal follows her. The closure of the padlock is heard again. Dorota moves into the kitchen, wets a towel, and returns to the bedside. Kneeling beside Szpilman, she tenderly places the cool, damp towel on his fevered brow, offering comfort. He manages to focus on her and offers a weary smile but suddenly winces in pain. She gazes at him with deep concern, her words barely audible. The Doctor and Michal quietly leave his line of sight, moving silently away.

From a vantage point at a window on the fourth floor, Szpilman gazes downwards, observing a landscape of peace. A few pedestrians meander below, contributing to a scene of everyday normalcy. In the distance, at the T-junction with a main road, a tram makes its way down the street, eventually coming to a halt as it disgorges passengers on the far side, momentarily slipping out of sight. The tram then resumes its journey, now revealing the few passengers who had alighted—women and an elderly man leaning on a stick, slowly making their way along the path.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Michal enters the room carrying a bag filled with provisions, making his way to the table to carefully place the bag down. As he does so, Szpilman strides immediately towards the window, drawn by the view outside. He gazes out to see the sprawling cityscape, his eyes traveling to the street below where directly across stands a hospital. On the corner, a building prominently displaying a Nazi flag catches his attention, guarded by a sentry stationed beside his sentry-box. Michal quietly approaches Szpilman from behind, heading towards the door with a nod before exiting the room. The sound of the padlock being locked resonates as Szpilman turns his focus back to the room, his eyes landing on the piano. He is motionless for a moment, then approaches the piano, seating himself on the stool. He adjusts the height carefully to his liking, lifts the lid, and gently removes the cloth covering the keys. Gazing with affection at the keyboard, he takes a deep breath and flexes his fingers in anticipation. With his fingers poised just above the keys, he begins to play with great passion, though no sound is produced. Snow falls softly outside as Szpilman remains alert, the sound of the padlock being unlocked drawing his attention. The door opens as Michal returns, accompanied by a man approximately thirty years old, Szalas, who exudes confidence and a touch of brashness. In hushed tones, Szalas and Szpilman exchange handshakes. Szalas retrieves a quarter bottle of vodka, and with a firm thump on the back of the bottle, he causes the cork to pop out. He locates glasses, pours the vodka, and distributes them to the others. Szalas nonchalantly shrugs, pours another round, and unwraps a package to reveal sausage and bread. He takes a bite of the sausage, chewing slowly and deliberately. He then moves towards the window to glance outside. With a thoughtful expression, Szpilman removes his wristwatch and hands it to Szalas, who slips it into his pocket. Szalas approaches the door, stops momentarily, grins, downs Szpilman's vodka in one swift motion, offers a mock salute, and departs, the padlock clicking into place once more. Sunlight pours through the windows as Szpilman lies motionless on the bed, weakened, starving, and ill. The familiar sound of the padlock signals the arrival of Dorota, no longer pregnant, and Michal as they enter and approach the bed. In whispers, Szpilman barely manages to open his eyes and focus on their presence, mumbling incoherently. She begins to head towards the door, and he follows suit. The padlock clicks again. Dorota moves to the kitchen, wets a towel, and returns to the bed to kneel beside it, gently placing the damp towel on Szpilman's brow. He shifts his focus onto her face, offering a faint smile before suddenly wincing in pain. She gazes at him, her words barely audible, as the Doctor and Michal exit his line of vision. Szpilman finds himself looking down from the fourth-floor window, observing the serene scene below. A few pedestrians wander by in an atmosphere of normalcy. At the far end, where the street intersects with a main road, a tram trundles along, coming to a stop to unload passengers out of sight. The tram continues its journey, now revealing the few passengers who disembarked: women and an elderly man leaning on a stick.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Michal arrives with provisions, placing them on the table as Szpilman peers out the window, noting a hospital and a Nazi-flagged building guarded by a sentry below. Michal nods goodbye, locks the door, and departs. Szpilman surveys the room, approaches the piano, adjusts the stool, uncovers the keys, and lovingly flexes his fingers above them, playing passionately without touching them. Snow falls as the sound of the padlock being unlocked signals Michal's return with Szalas, an assured, brash man. Szalas and Szpilman exchange whispered greetings, then Szalas opens a vodka bottle, pours drinks, and shares sausage and bread. Szalas gazes out the window before accepting Szpilman's wristwatch, gives a mock salute after drinking Szpilman's vodka, and leaves, locking the padlock behind him. Sunshine later reveals Szpilman weak and ill on the bed. The padlock sounds again as Dorota, no longer pregnant, and Michal enter quietly. Szpilman struggles to open his eyes, muttering incoherently as they leave. Dorota wets a towel in the kitchen, returns to place it on Szpilman's brow, prompting a weak smile before he winces in pain. She gazes at him, barely audible. Later, Szpilman looks down from the fourth-floor window onto a peaceful street below, observing everyday life—few pedestrians and a tram unloading passengers, including women and an elderly man with a stick.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Michal carries a bag of provisions, likely scarce and precious during wartime, and puts them on a table while Szpilman goes immediately to the window and looks out. There are views of the city, which has been ravaged by conflict, but in the street below, opposite, is a hospital treated as a rare sanctuary among devastation, and, on the corner, a building flying a Nazi flag and guarded by a sentry, standing at his sentry-box as a constant reminder of occupation. Michal comes up behind Szpilman, makes for the door, nods, and goes. The sound of the padlock closing, a measure both for security and containment. Szpilman takes in the room, sees the piano, a symbol of his former life and career interrupted by war, is still for a moment, then goes to it. He sits on the piano stool, adjusts its height, opens the lid, removes a cloth covering the keys, gazes lovingly at the keyboard, and flexes his fingers, once renowned for their skill. Then, without touching the keys, his fingers floating just above them, he plays passionately in his mind, a silent symphony echoing his lost freedom. Snow falling, a quiet but persistent reminder of the harsh winter outside. Szpilman alert, hearing the padlock being unlocked and then opened. The door opens and Michal enters, accompanied by a man, aged about thirty, Szalas, confident, a little brash, likely representing the black market traders thriving amidst shortages. In whispers, Szalas and Szpilman shake hands. Szalas produces a quarter bottle of vodka, a scarce luxury, thumps the back of the bottle so that the cork flies out. He finds glasses and pours, gives the others their vodka, a brief respite from their troubles. Szalas shrugs, finds the vodka, pours two glasses, unwraps the package to reveal sausage and bread, a simple but vital meal, takes a bite of sausage, chewing deliberately, slowly to savor each morsel. Szalas goes to the window, looks out. Szpilman thinks for a moment, then takes off his wristwatch, a valuable barter item in such times, hands it to Szalas. Szalas pockets the watch, makes for the door, stops, grins, downs Szpilman's vodka, gives a mock salute and goes. The padlock is locked on the other side, a reminder of the constant threat outside. Sunshine floods in through the windows, temporarily warming the cold room. Szpilman lies inert on the bed, weak, starving, ill, symptoms of the relentless privations he faces. The sound of the padlock, the daily ritual of precarious comings and goings. Dorota, no longer pregnant, and Michal enter, come to the bed. In whispers, Szpilman barely has strength to open his eyes and focus on them. He mutters incoherently, his mind clouded by fever and hunger. She starts for the door, and he leaves. The padlock sound signals yet another moment of vulnerability. Dorota goes to the kitchen, wets a towel, comes back to the bed, kneels, places the towel on Szpilman's brow, a small gesture of care and comfort. He focuses on her, smiles, then suddenly winces with pain, a sharp reminder of his frail condition. She looks at him, barely audible, her eyes full of concern. The Doctor and Michal leave his line of vision, moving out of sight but not out of mind. Szpilman looking down from the fourth-floor window, sees a world that carries on despite his suffering. Peaceful. A few pedestrians, brave souls venturing out. An everyday atmosphere, yet tinged with the constant undercurrent of tension. At the far end, at the T-junction with a main road, a tram rumbles down the street and comes to a halt, disgorging passengers on the far side and so out of sight. The tram continues on its way, now revealing the few passengers who alighted—women, an old man with a stick, each person bearing their own untold story shaped by the war.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. The padlock is locked on the other side. Sunshine floods in through the windows. Szpilman lies inert on the bed weak starving ill. The sound of the padlock. Dorota no longer pregnant and Michal enter come to the bed. In whispers. Szpilman barely has strength to open his eyes and focus on them. He mutters incoherently. She starts for the door and he leaves. The padlock sound. Dorota goes to the kitchen wets. a towel comes back to the bed kneels it places the towel on Szpilman's brow. He focuses on her smiles then suddenly winces with pain. She looks at him barely audible. The Doctor and Michal leave his line of vision. Szpilman looking down from the fourthfloor window. Peaceful. A few pedestrians. An everyday atmosphere. At the far end at the Tjunction with a main road a tram rumbles down the street and comes to a halt disgorging passengers on the far side and so out of sight. The tram continues on its way now revealing the few passengers who alighted—women. an old man with a stick.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: Michal carries a bag of provisions and puts them on a table while Szpilman goes immediately to the window and looks out. There are views of the city but in the street below opposite is a hospital and on the corner a building flying a Nazi flag and guarded by a sentry standing at his sentrybox. Michal comes up behind. Szpilman makes for the door nods and goes. The sound of the padlock closing. Szpilman takes in the room sees the piano is still for a moment then goes to it. He sits on the piano stool adjusts its height opens the lid removes a cloth covering the keys gazes lovingly at the keyboard and flexes his fingers. Then without touching the keys his fingers floating just above them he plays passionately. Snow falling. Szpilman alert hearing the padlock being unlocked and then opened. The door opens and Michal enters accompanied by a man aged about thirty. Szalas confident a little brash. In whispers. Szalas and Szpilman shake hands. Szalas produces a quarter bottle of vodka thumps the back of the bottle so that the cork flies out. He finds glasses and pours gives the others their vodka. Szalas shrugs finds the vodka pours two glasses unwraps the package to reveal sausage and bread takes a bite of sausage chewing deliberately. slowly. Szalas goes to the window looks out. Szpilman thinks for a moment then takes off his wristwatch hands it to Szalas. Szalas pockets the watch makes for the door stops grins downs. Szpilman's vodka gives a mock salute and goes. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Carla hauls a basket of gadgets and sets them on a bench while Norton rushes directly to the mirror and peers in. There are glimpses of the countryside, but in the lane below, across, is a tavern and, at the intersection, a barn flying a pirate flag and watched by a watchman, lounging at his post. Carla sneaks up behind Norton, heads for the exit, winks, and departs. The echo of the latch fastening. Norton surveys the chamber, finds the harp, pauses briefly, then approaches it. He perches on the stool, modifies its angle, lifts the cover, discards a sheet draping the strings, stares fondly at the instrument, and flexes his hands. Then, without plucking the strings, his hands hovering just above them, he performs fervently. Leaves drifting. Norton alert, sensing the latch being unfastened and then swung open. The portal swings and Carla strides in, joined by a woman, aged about thirty, Rona, self-assured, somewhat bold. In murmurs, Rona and Norton clasp hands. Rona reveals a small flask of cider, taps the base of the flask so the stopper pops out. She locates mugs and fills, offers the others their cider. Rona shrugs, locates the cider, fills two mugs, unwraps the bundle to display cheese and crackers, takes a bite of cheese, munching thoughtfully, leisurely. Rona approaches the mirror, gazes out. Norton ponders momentarily, then removes his necklace, hands it to Rona. Rona pockets the necklace, heads for the exit, pauses, beams, gulps Norton's cider, gives a playful wave and departs. The latch is latched from the outside. Moonlight floods in through the openings. Norton sprawls motionless on the couch, frail, hungry, ailing. The echo of the latch. Grace, no longer sleepy, and Carla arrive, walk to the couch. In murmurs, Norton scarcely musters strength to open his eyes and center on them. He mumbles incoherently. She strides for the exit, and he exits. The latch sound. Grace walks to the pantry, dampens a rag, returns to the couch, bends it, places the rag on Norton's forehead. He centers on her, grins, then suddenly grimaces with discomfort. She peers at him, barely audible. The Baker and Carla drift from his line of sight. Norton gazing down from the third-floor terrace. Serene. A couple of cyclists. A mundane air. At the far corner, at the crossroads with a major avenue, a carriage rolls down the path and stops, unloading riders on the far side and thus out of view. The carriage proceeds on its course, now uncovering the few riders who disembarked—men, a young girl with a balloon.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Szpilman immediately surveys the city from his window, noticing a Nazi-flagged building with a sentry. Michal arrives, briefly nods at Szpilman, locks the door, and leaves. Szpilman, captivated by a piano, lovingly prepares to play but stops just above the keys. Later, Michal returns with Szalas, bringing vodka and food. Szpilman trades his watch with Szalas, who locks the door as he leaves. Szpilman lies weak and starving in bed until Dorota and Michal visit. Dorota comforts him, placing a wet towel on his brow as Szpilman winces in pain. Peace returns outside with trams rumbling and pedestrians walking quietly, contrasting with Szpilman’s struggles inside.
